title: 1  Overview
text:
1.1 What You’ll Learn
Part III: Analyzing Quantitative Data {.unnumbered}
Section Editors: Shane McCarty, PhD & Zihan Hei
This section of the FRI Public Health Playbook focuses on quantitative data analysis methods essential for public health research. We cover the complete workflow from data import through advanced statistical analysis and visualization.
In this section, you will:

title: 1  Overview
text:
Master data import techniques for various file formats commonly used in public health research
Learn to clean, transform, and prepare data for analysis
Apply descriptive and inferential statistics to public health datasets
Create publication-quality visualizations
Interpret and communicate quantitative findings effectively

title: 1  Overview
text:
1.2 Section Contents
This section includes the following chapters:

Importing and Visualizing NHANES Data - Learn the fundamentals of data import and exploration using the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey dataset
Additional chapters on statistical analysis (coming soon)
Advanced visualization techniques (coming soon)

title: 1  Overview
text:
1.3 Prerequisites
Before beginning this section, you should have:

Basic familiarity with R or another statistical programming language
Understanding of fundamental statistical concepts
Access to a web browser (for WebR interactive examples)

title: 1  Overview
text:
1.4 About the Section Editors
Shane McCarty, PhD is the lead author of the FRI Public Health Playbook and specializes in quantitative methods for public health research.
Zihan Hei is a contributing researcher focusing on data visualization and statistical analysis in public health contexts.

Let’s begin with importing and exploring real public health data!

title: The FRI Public Health Playbook for Quantitative Data Analysis
text:
Preface
The most successful sports teams rely on well-designed plays to navigate complex game situations, the FRI Public Health research stream uses strategic data analysis “plays” to tackle the multifaceted challenges of promoting wellbeing, preventing disease, and protecting health. Our research stream explores the intricate biopsychosocial factors affecting human physical and mental health by collecting physiological data through wearables like MUSE S and Fitbits, psychological insights via survey questionnaires and interviews, and behavioral patterns through online experiments. Like a coach calling the right play at the crucial moment, this playbook equips you and your research teams with proven strategies for importing, tidying, transforming, visualizing, modeling, and communicating the mixed-methods data that helps us connect the dots between social, political, commercial, and economic determinants of health behavior, outcomes, and inequities. Each “play” in this guide has been field-tested by research teams who have successfully used quantitative and qualitative approaches to answer pressing questions about physical and mental health. Whether you’re facing a complex dataset for the first time or looking to refine your analytical strategy, this playbook offers guidance for you to turn data into information, information into knowledge, and knowledge into wisdom in order to improve public health outcomes.
To learn more about the FRI Public Health stream, visit us at: https://fripublichealth.quarto.pub.

title: 3  Using Functions to Write: From Text to Code
text:
3.1 Chapter Purpose
In reproducible research, writing numbers manually (e.g., “We surveyed 120 people.”) can lead to errors if you import data later (after you have collected 140 people). Instead, use R functions inside Quarto to turn your results directly into sentences!
crumbs: 3  Using Functions to Write: From Text to Code

text:

Students will work with this example zerosum dataset select_data.csv:

# Load your data
select_data <- read.csv("select_data.csv")

# displays structures of R objects
str(select_data)

title: 3  Using Functions to Write: From Text to Code
section: 3.7 In your manuscript, write like this:
text:
3.7 In your manuscript, write like this:

Out of `r total_responses` participants, The final sample was roughly balanced in terms of 
racial identity (White: `r percent(white, accuracy = 0.1)`, 
                 Black: `r percent(black, accuracy = 0.1)`,
                 Asian: `r percent(asian, accuracy = 0.1)`, 
                 Mixed/Other: `r percent(mixed_other, accuracy = 0.1)`).

When you render the output, you’ll get:

Out of 122 participants, The final sample was roughly balanced in terms of racial identity
(White: 40.2%, Black: 23.0%, Asian: 18.9%, Mixed/Other: 18.0%).

title: 3  Using Functions to Write: From Text to Code
section: 3.10 Example 4: Interpret a table by using inline R code (Mean, SD, Range)
text:
3.10 Example 4: Interpret a table by using inline R code (Mean, SD, Range)

# Define Continuous Variables
continuous_vars <- c(
  "AGE", "SOCIALSTATUS", "POLITICALBELIEFS",
  paste0("ZEROSUM_", 1:11)
)

desc_table_continuous <- select_data %>%
  select(all_of(continuous_vars)) %>%
  psych::describe() %>%
  tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "Variable") %>%
  select(Variable, n, mean, median, sd, min, max)

# Remove font specifications from nice_table
knitr::kable(desc_table_continuous,
             digits = 2)

title: 3  Using Functions to Write: From Text to Code
section: 3.11 In your manuscript, write like this:
text:
3.11 In your manuscript, write like this:

Descriptive statistics for all study variables are presented in Continuous Descriptive Statistics Table. 
The sample consisted of `r nrow(select_data)` participants, 
with a mean age of `r round(desc_table_continuous$mean[desc_table_continuous$Variable == "AGE"], 2)` 
years (SD = `r round(desc_table_continuous$sd[desc_table_continuous$Variable == "AGE"], 2)`, 
range = `r desc_table_continuous$min[desc_table_continuous$Variable == "AGE"]`
– `r desc_table_continuous$max[desc_table_continuous$Variable == "AGE"]`). 

Participants reported a mean social status of 
`r round(desc_table_continuous$mean[desc_table_continuous$Variable == "SOCIALSTATUS"], 2)` 
(SD = `r round(desc_table_continuous$sd[desc_table_continuous$Variable == "SOCIALSTATUS"], 2)`) on a 10-point scale.

When you render the output, you’ll get:

Descriptive statistics for all study variables are presented in Continuous Descriptive Statistics Table. 
The sample consisted of 122 participants, with a mean age of 36.1 years (SD = 12.73, range = 19 – 73). 
Participants reported a mean social status of 5.3 (SD = 1.78) on a 10-point scale.

title: 3  Using Functions to Write: From Text to Code
section: 3.13 In your manuscript, write like this:
text:
3.13 In your manuscript, write like this:

There was no significant difference in ZEROSUM_1 scores across political party groups, 
Kruskal-Wallis χ²(`r kw.ZEROSUM_1.party$parameter`) = `r round(kw.ZEROSUM_1.party$statistic, 2)`, 
*p* = `r signif(kw.ZEROSUM_1.party$p.value, 3)`.

When you render the output, you’ll get:

There was no significant difference in ZEROSUM_1 scores across political party groups, 
Kruskal-Wallis χ²(2) = 1.5, p = 0.473.

title: 3  Import
text:
# Install required packages
install.packages("NHANES")
install.packages("tidyverse")
install.packages("GGally")
install.packages("iris")

# Load the packages
library(NHANES)
library(tidyverse)
library(GGally)

Now, you will view the structure of the NHANES data

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook
text:
1.1 The Data Analysis Workflow
Students in the FRI Public Health research stream at Binghamton University explore a variety of biopsychosocial factors affecting human physical and mental health. This playbook includes a variety of “plays” (R code) that students in the quantitative data analysis track can use for their team-based research projects.
This playbook follows the data science workflow in R for Data Science (2e) (Hadley, 2023) to help researchers examine the prevalence of disease and wellbeing indicators, describe health patterns, identify associations between (risk/protective/promotive) determinants and (positive/negative) health outcomes, and produce a reproducible scientific report with R and Quarto.
Each section builds on previous concepts, taking you from raw data files to polished, publication-ready analyses.
crumbs: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook

title: 3  Using Functions to Write: From Text to Code
text:
3.2 First Setup the library:

library(tidyverse)
library(psych)
library(knitr)
library(tibble)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(scales)     # for number formatting like comma()
library(english)    # to convert numbers to words
library(stringr)    # for text functions like str_c()
crumbs: 3  Using Functions to Write: From Text to Code

title: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations
text:
7.1 The ggplot2 Package
Recall: Packages are collections of code, data, and documentation that add extra functionality not included in base R.
To install and load ggplot2:
install.packages("ggplot2")
crumbs: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations

title: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook
text:
1.2 What You’ll Learn
By the end of this book, you will be able to:

Import and manage data from multiple file formats commonly used in public health (CSV, Excel, SPSS, SAS)
Clean and prepare datasets for analysis using tidyverse tools
Transform variables by recoding, creating dummy variables, and calculating composite scores
Create publication-quality visualizations that effectively communicate health data
Apply statistical models including regression, paired tests, and other inferential methods
Generate reproducible reports that integrate code, results, and narrative
Follow best practices for transparent, reproducible public health research
crumbs: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook

title: 1  Overview
text:
1.2 Section Contents
This section includes the following chapters:

Importing and Visualizing NHANES Data - Learn the fundamentals of data import and exploration using the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey dataset
Additional chapters on statistical analysis (coming soon)
Advanced visualization techniques (coming soon)

title: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook
text:
1.4 Prerequisites
Technical Requirements:
- A web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge) for interactive WebR examples
- Optional: R and RStudio installed for local work (instructions provided in Chapter 1)
Background Knowledge:
- Basic familiarity with public health concepts - Introductory statistics (descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, p-values)
- Willingness to learn programming (no prior R experience required!)
crumbs: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook

1.4 About the Section Editors
Shane McCarty, PhD is the lead author of the FRI Public Health Playbook and specializes in quantitative methods for public health research.
Zihan Hei is a contributing researcher focusing on data visualization and statistical analysis in public health contexts.

Let’s begin with importing and exploring real public health data!

title: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations
text:
7.2 Example Dataset: Insurance Charges
Let’s start by loading our dataset and exploring it:

insurance <- read.csv("data/insurance.csv")


library(ggplot2)


7.2.1 Summarizing Our Data
Let’s learn more about our data with summary():

summary(insurance)

      age            sex                 bmi           children    
 Min.   :18.00   Length:1338        Min.   :15.96   Min.   :0.000  
 1st Qu.:27.00   Class :character   1st Qu.:26.30   1st Qu.:0.000  
 Median :39.00   Mode  :character   Median :30.40   Median :1.000  
 Mean   :39.21                      Mean   :30.66   Mean   :1.095  
 3rd Qu.:51.00                      3rd Qu.:34.69   3rd Qu.:2.000  
 Max.   :64.00                      Max.   :53.13   Max.   :5.000  
    smoker             region             charges     
 Length:1338        Length:1338        Min.   : 1122  
 Class :character   Class :character   1st Qu.: 4740  
 Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Median : 9382  
                                       Mean   :13270  
                                       3rd Qu.:16640  
                                       Max.   :63770  



head(insurance, 10)

   age    sex    bmi children smoker    region   charges
1   19 female 27.900        0    yes southwest 16884.924
2   18   male 33.770        1     no southeast  1725.552
3   28   male 33.000        3     no southeast  4449.462
4   33   male 22.705        0     no northwest 21984.471
5   32   male 28.880        0     no northwest  3866.855
6   31 female 25.740        0     no southeast  3756.622
7   46 female 33.440        1     no southeast  8240.590
8   37 female 27.740        3     no northwest  7281.506
9   37   male 29.830        2     no northeast  6406.411
10  60 female 25.840        0     no northwest 28923.137
crumbs: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations

title: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations
text:
7.3 The Seven Components of ggplot2
Think of building a ggplot like making a layered lasagna - you add one component at a time to create the final product. The seven components are:

Data: The dataset you’re visualizing
Mapping: Which variables go on which axes (aesthetics)
Geometries: The type of plot (points, lines, bars, etc.)
Facets: Subplots based on categorical variables
Statistics: Statistical transformations of the data
Coordinates: The coordinate system (usually Cartesian)
Theme: Visual styling and appearance




In ggplot2, add layers as you would in making lasagna
crumbs: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations

title: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations
text:
7.4 Understanding Data Types
Before creating visualizations, it’s important to understand your data types:
Qualitative Data:

🏷️ Nominal Data: Categories without any order (e.g., Red, Green, Blue)
📶 Ordinal Data: Categories with some order (e.g., Small, Medium, Large)

Quantitative Data:

🔢 Discrete: Countable data (e.g., number of people in a room)
📏 Continuous: Measurable data (e.g., height, weight)
crumbs: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations

title: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations
section: 7.5 Building a Plot Step by Step
text:
7.5 Building a Plot Step by Step

7.5.1 Step 1: Data and Mapping
What is the relationship between BMI and insurance charges?

ggplot(data = insurance, mapping = aes(x = bmi, y = charges))








This creates a blank canvas with our axes defined, but no data displayed yet!


7.5.2 Step 2: Adding Layers with Geometries
Add points to create a scatterplot using geom_point():

ggplot(data = insurance, mapping = aes(x = bmi, y = charges)) + 
  geom_point()










7.5.3 Step 3: Adding a Trend Line
Add a linear model line with geom_smooth():

ggplot(data = insurance, mapping = aes(x = bmi, y = charges)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")








Notice how it looks like we have two different populations? Let’s explore this further.
crumbs: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations

title: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations
text:
7.6 Incorporating Grouping Variables
There are two main approaches to visualizing grouping variables:

7.6.1 Method 1: Using Color
Map the smoker variable to color:

ggplot(data = insurance, 
       mapping = aes(x = bmi, y = charges, color = smoker)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")










7.6.2 Method 2: Using Facets
Create separate panels for each group with facet_wrap():

ggplot(data = insurance, mapping = aes(x = bmi, y = charges)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  facet_wrap(~smoker)








Both methods reveal that smoking status significantly affects the relationship between BMI and insurance charges!
crumbs: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations

title: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations
text:
7.7 Customizing with Themes

7.7.1 Adding Titles and Labels
Make your plot more informative with descriptive titles:

ggplot(data = insurance, mapping = aes(x = bmi, y = charges, color = smoker)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  ggtitle("Insurance charges vs BMI for smokers and non-smokers") +
  xlab("Body Mass Index (BMI)") +
  ylab("Insurance Charges")










7.7.2 Changing the Theme
Apply a professional theme with theme_bw():

ggplot(data = insurance, mapping = aes(x = bmi, y = charges, color = smoker)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  ggtitle("Insurance charges vs BMI for smokers and non-smokers") +
  xlab("Body Mass Index (BMI)") +
  ylab("Insurance Charges") +
  theme_bw()




a scatterplot depicting a linear relationship between BMI and insurance charges
crumbs: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations

title: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations
text:
7.8 Other Common Plot Types

7.8.1 Bar Plots with geom_bar()
Bar plots are useful for comparing means across categories:

ggplot(data = insurance, mapping = aes(x = region, y = charges)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = 'summary', fun = 'mean', fill = "#005a43") + 
  ggtitle("Mean Insurance Charges Based on Region") + 
  xlab("Region") +
  ylab("Insurance Charges") +
  theme_bw()










7.8.2 Violin Plots with geom_violin()
Violin plots show the distribution of data across categories:

ggplot(data = insurance, mapping = aes(x = smoker, y = charges, fill = smoker)) + 
  geom_violin() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Insurance Charges by Smoking Status") +
  xlab("Smoker (Y/N)") +
  ylab("Insurance Charges") +
  theme_bw()
crumbs: 7  Introduction to ggplot2: Creating publication-ready visualizations

title: 5  Data Manipulation with dplyr: Cleaning and Transforming Data
text:
5.1 Introduction to dplyr
dplyr is part of the tidyverse and provides intuitive functions for manipulating data. Think of it as a toolkit for cleaning and preparing your data for analysis.
Why use dplyr?
crumbs: 5  Data Manipulation with dplyr: Cleaning and Transforming Data

title: 5  Data Manipulation with dplyr: Cleaning and Transforming Data
text:
Makes data cleaning code readable and logical
Uses the pipe operator (%>%) to chain operations together
Essential for preparing data before creating visualizations or running analyses


Remember: You cannot create meaningful visualizations or run valid statistical analyses without clean data!
crumbs: 5  Data Manipulation with dplyr: Cleaning and Transforming Data

title: 5  Data Manipulation with dplyr: Cleaning and Transforming Data
text:
5.2 Example 1: Recoding Education into Categories
When working with survey data, we often need to collapse detailed response categories into broader groups. This is useful for:

Simplifying analysis
Creating groups with adequate sample sizes
Making results easier to interpret


5.2.1 Original Education Variable
Our survey asked about education level with 7 response options:

Less than high school
High school diploma or GED
Some college, but no degree
Associate’s or technical degree
Bachelor’s degree
Master’s degree
Doctoral or professional degree



5.2.2 Recoding into Three Categories
Let’s group these into three meaningful categories:

# Create a new 3-category education variable
alldata <- alldata %>%
  mutate(
    education_3cat = factor(
      case_when(
        Education_Level %in% c(1, 2, 3, 4) ~ "Less than Bachelor's",
        Education_Level == 5 ~ "Bachelor's Degree",
        Education_Level %in% c(6, 7) ~ "Graduate Degree"
      ),
      levels = c("Less than Bachelor's", "Bachelor's Degree", "Graduate Degree")
    )
  )

# Check the recoding with a cross-tabulation
table(alldata$Education_Level, alldata$education_3cat, useNA = "ifany")

   
    Less than Bachelor's Bachelor's Degree Graduate Degree
  1                   11                 0               0
  2                   17                 0               0
  3                    8                 0               0
crumbs: 5  Data Manipulation with dplyr: Cleaning and Transforming Data

title: 1  Overview
text:
1.4 About the Authors
Shane McCarty, PhD developed the FRI Public Health Playbook with a team of collaborating Binghamton students to support quantitative data analysis in R for public health research.
Zihan Heiis a contributing researcher focusing on data visualization and statistical analysis in public health contexts.

Let’s begin with importing and exploring real data!

title: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook
text:
Import - Load data from various sources, such as standard (.csv), Excel (.xlsx), and SPSS (.sav)
Tidy - Organize data into a consistent, analysis-ready structure
Transform - Clean, recode, and create new variables using dplyr
Visualize - Create informative graphs and charts with ggplot2
Model - Apply statistical methods to answer research questions
Communicate - Generate reproducible reports with Quarto



1.1.1 What Makes This Book Different?

Interactive Learning: Some code examples can be copy and pasted into your .R script, .qmd markdown report file, or run in the console. Some chapters include code examples that run directly in your browser using WebR—no software installation required
Real Public Health Data: Examples use datasets on insurance claims from kaggle, oral health and diabetes (cohort 10), health beliefs (cohort 11), and related surveys
Complete Workflow: Covers every step from raw data to publication-ready reports
Practical Focus: Emphasizes “plays” (R code chunks) you’ll actually use in public health research and practice
crumbs: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook

title: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook
text:
1.3 Book Structure

1.3.1 Part 1: Importing Data
Learn to bring data into R from various sources, including exporting from Qualtrics and importing common file formats.
Chapters:
- Exporting Data from Survey Platforms
- Importing Data into R (CSV, Excel, SPSS, and more)


1.3.2 Part 2: Tidy Data
Understand the principles of tidy data and how to reshape datasets for analysis.
Chapters:
- Tidying Data with tidyr


1.3.3 Part 3: Transform Data
Master data manipulation techniques to prepare your data for analysis.
Chapters:
- Data Manipulation with dplyr (filtering, recoding, creating variables)


1.3.4 Part 4: Visualize Data
Create effective visualizations that reveal patterns and communicate findings.
Chapters:
- Introduction to ggplot2 (scatterplots, bar charts, distributions)


1.3.5 Part 5: Model Data
Apply statistical methods to test hypotheses and quantify relationships.
Chapters:
- Regression Analysis
- Paired and Related Samples Tests


1.3.6 Part 6: Quarto Reporting
Learn to create reproducible, professional reports that integrate your analysis.
Chapters:
- Using Functions to Write: From Text to Code (inline R, dynamic reporting)
crumbs: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook

title: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook
crumbs: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook

title: 1  Welcome to the FRI Public Health Playbook
text:
1.6 How to Cite This Book
Use #comment to source your code chunks if you copy and paste any code from this playbook. McCarty, S. (Ed.). (2025). The FRI Public Health Playbook. https://fripublichealth.quarto.pub/playbook

1.6.1 Authors

Editor: Shane McCarty, PhD
Chapter Authors

Zihan Hei
Gavin Rualo


After generating original content, claude.ai was used to create chapter summaries based on the chapter content and code. Ai was also used to refine existing code chunks.
